betsy.memory

Class Context

  • java.lang.Object
    • betsy.memory.Context

  • public class Context
extends java.lang.Object
    The Context class is used to keep track of what generic pronouns like "him," "her," "it," "them," etc. refer to, based on nouns that the user has talked about in previous sentences. It keeps track of four types of prounouns: "him," for male people (based on a list of common male names), "her," for female people (based on a list of common female names), "it" for generic singular objects, and "them" for generic plural objects or people.
    Author:
    jacob

      • interpretContext

        public void interpretContext(WordTree<StructureTag> phrase)
        Interpret a user's sentence, pick out the nouns and store them as the pronouns that could be used to refer to them.
        Parameters:
        phrase - the phrase, as a WordTree, to interpret and search for nouns

      • replaceContext

        public void replaceContext(WordTree<StructureTag> phrase)
        Replace pronouns in the phrase like "him," "her," etc. with their most likely meaning. Not all pronouns will be replaced -- some may not have a match.
        Parameters:
        phrase - the phrase to scan and replace. A new WordTree isn't created -- the existing one is modified in place.

      • getContextFromPronoun

        public WordTree<StructureTag> getContextFromPronoun(java.lang.String pronoun)
        Given a pronoun word (he, she, they, it, etc.), get the noun-phrase, based on the user's recent sentences, most likely meant by it.
        Parameters:
        pronoun - the pronoun word
        Returns:
        a noun-phrase, in the form of a WordTree with root NOUN_PHRASE

      • getContextDescription

        public java.lang.String getContextDescription(SentenceConstructor constructor)
        Get the current state of the context as a human-readable string.
        Parameters:
        constructor - the SentenceConstructor used to turn phrase trees into human-readable strings.
        Returns:
        a String describing the current context
